newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Caltex says second half gains eroded.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Caltex says second half gains eroded.

text.p: Caltex Australia Ltd on Wednesday reported a 35 percent rise in its full year net profit for calendar 1996 against 1995, but said gains had been eroded by outside factors in the second half.
Caltex, which jointly owns petrol refiner Australian Petroleum Pty Ltd (Ampol) with Pioneer International Ltd, reported a net profit for 1996 of A$57.70 million.
Chairman Malcolm Irving told a briefing the profit reflected A$52.4 million from Ampol and A$10.6 million from the sale of a stake in the Bayswater colliery in New South Wales.

It also included a A$3.0 million loss on Bayswater's operations and a A$2.4 million loss from closing out interest rate swaps. Irving said Ampol's second half result fell sharply on the first half, although the refiner lifted 1996 calendar year net profit to A$104.86 million from A$93.35 million.
Second half earnings were A$38.6 million, compared with a first half result near A$70 million, he said.
Irving said efficiency measures had brought significant cost savings, but gains had been eroded by a fall in Singapore refiner margins due to new refinery capacity.
This resulted in surplus production of petrol, while increased demand for light crudes led to physical supply difficulties.
"This combination of factors had a severe effect on margins and revenues, particularly in the second half of the year," Caltex said.
Ampol managing director Ian Blackburne said operating costs fell by A$43 million in 1996 on the previous year, while Ampol sold A$51 million worth of assets.
"All in all, there has been a very significant improvement in the underlying performance...offset in part by external factors," he said.
Blackburne said he expected to make a further A$20 million in cost reductions in 1997.
He expected Singapore petrol refiner margins to improve gradually during the current half and probably continue to improve in the second half.
"I think, though, we shouldn't expect full year refining margins to be much higher than they were in 1996," he said.
